bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Wickliffe Rose, February 10, 1923

div1.p: Noguchi gives his opinion on a possible infectious jaundice case in Guayaquil, and requests clinical data.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Wickliffe Rose, February 10, 1923
div1.opener:
Carter
COPY
The Rockefeller Institute for
Medical Research
66th street and avenue A
New York City
February 10, 1923
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
Dr Russell brought me your letter and the accompanying
report of Dr Coello.

There is of course a possibility of confusion in these
cases of infectious jaundice, a disease which has not been present
in Guayaquil before. The four cases which died before the 6th day
are especially difficult to explain, since infectious jaundice
patients seldom die before the 6th or 7th and usually not until the
9th day. In yellow fever, on the other hand, death usually occurs
on the 5th or 6th day. The mortality is high for infectious jaun-
dice (57%) and more like yellow fever. However, I do not feel
like questioning their diagnosis, especially as the preliminary an-
nouncement in the Journal of the American Medical Association states
that the study is being continued and that the relation between the
organism isolated and Leptospira icterohaemorrhagiae is being de-
termined. I would suggest that we inquire whether the study has been
completed and with what results, and I should be glad to offer my
strains of Leptospira icterohaemorrhagiae for comparison if they are
desired.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, (Signed) Hideyo Noguchi Dr Wickliffe Rose
International Health Board
61 Broadway, New York, N Y
P S I am writing Dr Pareja asking him to let me have clinical and
experimental data regarding these cases. A detailed report will be
of great value in establishing the diagnosis of infectious jaundice
in a region where yellow fever had been prevalent up to a few years
ago.
